title: Be Civil When Offering Advice
body:
Just a reminder that if you're going to try and help someone improve at League, you really ought to be polite, civil and respectful while doing so.

Unfortunately, it's fairly common for more skilled players to speak harshly, condescendingly, or derogatorily to or about less skilled players, even when trying to help them. If we want our community to be safe, welcoming, and healthy, this needs to stop, and all players need to be committed to fostering a culture of kindness, decency, and self-improvement.

Cheers!

replies.body: Being a overly positive cheerful player is over-rated I mean unless your suggesting this community be a bubble and pretend life is grand.

Because living in a sea of toxicity is soooo much better. He's not asking for you to go around giving flowers and hugs, just to keep your derogatory comments to yourself and be respectful.

If you're going to be looking at this in a logical manner (since no one is perfect), raging at someone solves nothing, so if you want to win the game the whole team needs to be in sync and coordinated. Nothing wrecks that faster then a loss of self-confidence and a sense of dejection from your team.

Living in a sea of toxicity? This seems exaggerated. I feel it's rather insulting that people are easily offended in game and don't seem to be able or willing to take suggestions. For every post like this, there should be a post for new players reminding them that intent is hard to read  over the internet and there are a lot that can be learned from the more veteran players.

Very true, but I think there are a ton of cases where you can promote better environments to play a game in and still be clearly respectful.
****
* Why did you do that?

As opposed to,

* We need to group
***
* Don't try to 1v2

This seems demanding, people don't like being told what to do (case in point me asking you to be nicer)

* I was coming for you :(

That tells them you care about the game and whether or not they do good. You wanted to help, they just had a lapse of judgment.
***
In the end, I can't control anyone's choices, and neither can you, but you can choose how you react to a situation, and whether or not you want to set yourself apart as a example of sportsmanship.

Loving the sentiment of this thread! It's interesting to me; it's awesome when someone helps me get better, but it can also be really tough to "teach" someone else in a way that doesn't come off as patronizing or condescending.

> In the end, I can't control anyone's choices, and neither can you, but you can choose how you react to a situation, and whether or not you want to set yourself apart as a example of sportsmanship.

This is well said. Communication is a two-way street, and it can be tough to remember that you've only got the management of one end of it.

I've personally found that, as early as champ select, it's fairly straightforward to switch the team's tone to a collaborative one rather than an antagonistic one by saying something strategic & team-ish, like "oh nice, we have Amumu. If we get a few more AOE ults, teamfights could be super easy for us." You're giving your team some of your game knowledge in a way that doesn't feel like a lecture, and you're opening up one of the right things to talk about--ways for the team to win.

It's also nice to avoid negative terms like "We'll lose the game if you keep splitting", if you're going to assume the role of a 'team captain' you also have to be somewhat charismatic. Stuff like:

* I'll peel for Jinx, you guys worry about Trist.

* gj (seriously, these two letters feel real good, just say it after every kill or close play, really brings up moral)

* care for the Trynd split, we'll stop him as a group, so shove the wave now

Really goes a long way, if you sound desperate or angry the game doens't really become fun or engaging, just frustrating and (sometimes) toxic.

I totally agree that one person can easily set the tone for the whole game, I personally think one of the main reasons I got to Gold because I managed to set a good tone as many times as I possibly could. 

Positivity really does win games, because we can all keep cool heads and do damage control (not to mention way better communication).

A) Interactions
- Your attitude will affect how you play as well as how you interact.
If you go into a match while angry, any little thing can set you off, and you will start to rage instead of focusing on the match.
- Asking 'why' is almost always seen as an attack against someone, be it skill, knowledge or decisions, forcing them to focus on defending themselves rather than winning the game, it is a vicious cycle that can start simply with the word 'why'.
- If you want people to listen, be courteous, and try to explain why they should do something, instead of demanding that they do it.

Source 
http://forums.eune.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=723240

The OP didn't offer any new information relative to this topic that EVERYONE doesn't already know.  We all know we come off harsher than intended. We all know we need to a vigilant effort to improve player to player interaction. This thread is pointless. Your point was way more relevant the OP. 

Suggesting how to come off more civilized and nicer rather than telling people to be nicer.

Getting easily offended is one thing, but there's no need to go "Dude wtf is wrong with u!?" or something along those lines when someone makes a mistake.  It's unnecessary and you'll just piss off the other person. A lot of people take advantage of the fact that they're behind a screen to be condescending, assholes, etc. and people say that's okay because it's the internet. It's really not.

Don't get me wrong, overly cheerful players kinda give me the whole uncanny valley feeling of something ain't right, but I'd much rather take that over the average potty-mouthed child that plays this game.  It's ridiculous that the community outright endorses this shit.

Don't even offer advice. The children that play this game don't want to hear it and wouldn't admit a mistake so all it does is fuel fights. Frankly I wish I had an option to just turn off chat since everyone spouts out illogical and poorly reasoned gameplay strategies all day long.

EDIT: just to be clear i mean my own chat I start off with something like "braum dont waste q when ali is alone 10 ft behind turret that awy it isnt down when corki shows up"

immediately start getting trolled in return "PLAY YOUR OWN FUCKING HERO" yeah im laning with you...

Well a big portion of this community including veterans and pros don't offer advice, most pros that stream don't commentate either although it seems to be growing but generally the ones that do are the exception. Also guides and analysis of games are generally well received, so there is clearly summoners that want to learn.

In your example were you typing while still in lane? Because the fact he said "PLAY YOUR OWN FUCKING HERO" seems like he was upset that you were typing in lane and not laning, but I could be wrong since I'm just guessing.

Just a few personal tips for giving tips:

1. Type when it is appropriate to do so (while you're dead or recalling in a safe location) or after game if you really want to go out of your way.

2. Don't generalize e.g., telling your tank "don't engage" after he does a bad engage is bad advice. You could say something like "I don't think that engage was good, we were out of position to follow up *or* we are too far behind in gold, let us farm up a bit more."

3. Keep your thoughts personal e.g., I disagree with that or I don't think that was or I think we should is much better than saying that was bad or group pls. This game is very dynamic and what you might think is a good call might turn out very bad so when giving advice make sure you take a personal stance for your advice.

This is just what I have learned about giving tips over the years but at the end of the day it's just my opinion and I'm just trying to help.
We already live with 'no'. 'No' is frankly awful and fosters a culture of elitism and dickishness. We can and should be better than that.

> Just a reminder that if you're going to try and help someone improve at League, you really ought to be polite, civil and respectful while doing so.
> 
> Unfortunately, it's fairly common for more skilled players to speak harshly, condescendingly, or derogatorily to or about less skilled players, even when trying to help them. If we want our community to be safe, welcoming, and healthy, this needs to stop, and all players need to be committed to fostering a culture of kindness, decency, and self-improvement.
> 
> Cheers!

In reality, this sort of gaming community cannot understand your text intentions, so you may as well just NOT comment to them what you want from them just to be on the safe side.

One thing I forgot to mention, the end result of all this banning is that when I play games no one says a word the entire game. Like what's the point of even having chat now other than inhouses where all players know each other, which in my experience we all get on mumble ANYWAYS. It's bad enough that riot doesn't direct people to use the ingame mute feature (like putting it in the actual chat log instead of attached to a scoreboard) but now every single game I've played in is everyone afraid to say anything lest they somehow stir up shit and get hit with a negative attitude report.

I guess they might all be chat restricted, but that seems unlikely (plus some of them say GG on all chat at the end of the game so it certainly can't be everyone).

I approve but I can't do :D I have issues. xD

People who can't help themselves(google a guide/how to play etc it takes 5 minutes of your time and X amount of minutes to read.. seriously.. lazy kids these days disgust me...) Get no help from me.
